description: From Middle English disciple, discipul, from Old English discipul (“disciple, scholar”), from Latin discipulus (“pupil, learner”). Later influenced or superseded in Middle English by Old French deciple.

entries.meaning: A person who learns from another, especially one who then teaches others.
An active follower or adherent of someone, or some philosophy etc.
examples: And it came to pass, as Jesus sat at meat in the house, behold, many publicans and sinners came and sat down with him and his disciples.

verbs.description: disciple (third-person singular simple present disciples, present participle discipling, simple past and past participle discipled)

entries.meaning: (religion, transitive) To convert (a person) into a disciple.
(Christianity, certain denominations) To routinely counsel (one's peer or junior) one-on-one in their discipleship of Christ, as a fellow affirmed disciple.
